member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.SocketOptionName.IPProtectionLevel
member.summary: Enables restriction of a IPv6 socket to a specified scope, such as addresses with the same link local or site local prefix.This socket option enables applications to place access restrictions on IPv6 sockets. Such restrictions enable an application running on a private LAN to simply and robustly harden itself against external attacks. This socket option widens or narrows the scope of a listening socket, enabling unrestricted access from public and private users when appropriate, or restricting access only to the same site, as required. This socket option has defined protection levels specified in the enumeration.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.SocketOptionName.IpTimeToLive
member.summary: Set the IP header Time-to-Live field.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.SocketOptionName.IPv6Only
member.summary: Indicates if a socket created for the AF_INET6 address family is restricted to IPv6 communications only. Sockets created for the AF_INET6 address family may be used for both IPv6 and IPv4 communications. Some applications may want to restrict their use of a socket created for the AF_INET6 address family to IPv6 communications only. When this value is non-zero (the default on Windows), a socket created for the AF_INET6 address family can be used to send and receive IPv6 packets only. When this value is zero, a socket created for the AF_INET6 address family can be used to send and receive packets to and from an IPv6 address or an IPv4 address. Note that the ability to interact with an IPv4 address requires the use of IPv4 mapped addresses. This socket option is supported on Windows Vista or later.

member.name: T:System.Net.Sockets.SocketType
member.summary: Specifies the type of socket that an instance of the class represents.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.SocketType.Dgram
member.summary: Supports datagrams, which are connectionless, unreliable messages of a fixed (typically small) maximum length. Messages might be lost or duplicated and might arrive out of order. A of type requires no connection prior to sending and receiving data, and can communicate with multiple peers. uses the Datagram Protocol () and the .

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.SocketType.Raw
member.summary: Supports access to the underlying transport protocol. Using the , you can communicate using protocols like Internet Control Message Protocol () and Internet Group Management Protocol (). Your application must provide a complete IP header when sending. Received datagrams return with the IP header and options intact.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.SocketType.Rdm
member.summary: Supports connectionless, message-oriented, reliably delivered messages, and preserves message boundaries in data. Rdm (Reliably Delivered Messages) messages arrive unduplicated and in order. Furthermore, the sender is notified if messages are lost. If you initialize a Socket using , you do not require a remote host connection before sending and receiving data. With , you can communicate with multiple peers.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.SocketType.Seqpacket
member.summary: Provides connection-oriented and reliable two-way transfer of ordered byte streams across a network. does not duplicate data, and it preserves boundaries within the data stream. A Socket of type communicates with a single peer and requires a remote host connection before communication can begin.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.SocketType.Stream
member.summary: Supports reliable, two-way, connection-based byte streams without the duplication of data and without preservation of boundaries. A Socket of this type communicates with a single peer and requires a remote host connection before communication can begin. uses the Transmission Control Protocol () and the InterNetwork.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.SocketType.Unknown
member.summary: Specifies an unknown Socket type.

member.name: T:System.Net.Sockets.TransmitFileOptions
member.summary: The enumeration defines values used in file transfer requests.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.TransmitFileOptions.Disconnect
member.summary: Start a transport-level disconnect after all the file data has been queued for transmission. When used with , these flags return the socket to a disconnected, reusable state after the file has been transmitted.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.TransmitFileOptions.ReuseSocket
member.summary: The socket handle may be reused when the request completes. This flag is valid only if is also specified. When used with , these flags return the socket to a disconnected, reusable state after the file has been transmitted.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.TransmitFileOptions.UseDefaultWorkerThread
member.summary: Use the default thread to process long file transfer requests.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.TransmitFileOptions.UseKernelApc
member.summary: Use kernel asynchronous procedure calls (APCs) instead of worker threads to process long file transfer requests. Long requests are defined as requests that require more than a single read from the file or a cache; the request therefore depends on the size of the file and the specified length of the send packet.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.TransmitFileOptions.UseSystemThread
member.summary: Use system threads to process long file transfer requests.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.TransmitFileOptions.WriteBehind
member.summary: Complete the file transfer request immediately, without pending. If this flag is specified and the file transfer succeeds, the data has been accepted by the system but not necessarily acknowledged by the remote end. Do not use this flag with the and flags.

member.name: T:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode
member.summary: Specifies the IO control codes supported by the method.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.AbsorbRouterAlert
member.summary: This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_ABSORB_RTRALERT constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.AddMulticastGroupOnInterface
member.summary: Join a multicast group using an interface identified by its index. This control code is supported on Windows 2000 and later operating systems. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_INDEX_ADD_MCAST constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.AddressListChange
member.summary: Enable receiving notification when the list of local interfaces for the socket's protocol family changes. This control code is supported on Windows 2000 and later operating systems. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_ADDRESS_LIST_CHANGE constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.AddressListQuery
member.summary: Return the list of local interfaces that the socket can bind to. This control code is supported on Windows 2000 and later operating systems. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_ADDRESS_LIST_QUERY constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.AddressListSort
member.summary: Sort the structure returned by the field and add scope ID information for IPv6 addresses. This control code is supported on Windows XP and later operating systems. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_ADDRESS_LIST_SORT constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.AssociateHandle
member.summary: Associate this socket with the specified handle of a companion interface. Refer to the appropriate protocol-specific annex in the Winsock 2 reference or documentation for the particular companion interface for additional details. It is recommended that the Component Object Model (COM) be used instead of this IOCTL to discover and track other interfaces that might be supported by a socket. This control code is present for backward compatibility with systems where COM is not available or cannot be used for some other reason. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_ASSOCIATE_HANDLE constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.AsyncIO
member.summary: Enable notification for when data is waiting to be received. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 FIOASYNC constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.BindToInterface
member.summary: Bind the socket to a specified interface index. This control code is supported on Windows 2000 and later operating systems. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_INDEX_BIND constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.DataToRead
member.summary: Return the number of bytes available for reading. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 FIONREAD constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.DeleteMulticastGroupFromInterface
member.summary: Remove the socket from a multicast group. This control code is supported on Windows 2000 and later operating systems. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_INDEX_ADD_MCAST constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.EnableCircularQueuing
member.summary: Replace the oldest queued datagram with an incoming datagram when the incoming message queues are full. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_ENABLE_CIRCULAR_QUEUEING constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.Flush
member.summary: Discard the contents of the sending queue. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_FLUSH constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.GetBroadcastAddress
member.summary: Return a SOCKADDR structure that contains the broadcast address for the address family of the current socket. The returned address can be used with the method. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_GET_BROADCAST_ADDRESS constant. This value can be used on User Datagram Protocol (UDP) sockets only.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.GetExtensionFunctionPointer
member.summary: Obtain provider-specific functions that are not part of the Winsock specification. Functions are specified using their provider-assigned GUID. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_GET_EXTENSION_FUNCTION_POINTER constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.GetGroupQos
member.summary: Return the Quality of Service (QOS) attributes for the socket group. This value is reserved for future use, and is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_GET_GROUP_QOS constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.GetQos
member.summary: Retrieve the QOS structure associated with the socket. This control is only supported on platforms that provide a QOS capable transport (Windows Me, Windows 2000, and later.) This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_GET_QOS constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.KeepAliveValues
member.summary: Control sending TCP keep-alive packets and the interval at which they are sent. This control code is supported on Windows 2000 and later operating systems. For additional information, see RFC 1122 section 4.2.3.6. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_KEEPALIVE_VALS constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.LimitBroadcasts
member.summary: This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_LIMIT_BROADCASTS constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.MulticastInterface
member.summary: Set the interface used for outgoing multicast packets. The interface is identified by its index. This control code is supported on Windows 2000 and later operating systems. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_INDEX_MCASTIF constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.MulticastScope
member.summary: Control the number of times a multicast packet can be forwarded by a router, also known as the Time to Live (TTL), or hop count. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_MULTICAST_SCOPE constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.MultipointLoopback
member.summary: Control whether multicast data sent by the socket appears as incoming data in the sockets receive queue. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_MULTIPOINT_LOOPBACK constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.NamespaceChange
member.summary: Control whether the socket receives notification when a namespace query becomes invalid. This control code is supported on Windows XP and later operating systems. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_NSP_NOTIFY_CHANGE constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.NonBlockingIO
member.summary: Control the blocking behavior of the socket. If the argument specified with this control code is zero, the socket is placed in blocking mode. If the argument is nonzero, the socket is placed in nonblocking mode. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 FIONBIO constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.OobDataRead
member.summary: Return information about out-of-band data waiting to be received. When using this control code on stream sockets, the return value indicates the number of bytes available.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.QueryTargetPnpHandle
member.summary: Retrieve the underlying provider's SOCKET handle. This handle can be used to receive plug-and-play event notification. This control code is supported on Windows 2000 and later operating systems. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_QUERY_TARGET_PNP_HANDLE constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.ReceiveAll
member.summary: Enable receiving all IPv4 packets on the network. The socket must have address family , the socket type must be , and the protocol type must be . The current user must belong to the Administrators group on the local computer, and the socket must be bound to a specific port. This control code is supported on Windows 2000 and later operating systems. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_RCVALL constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.ReceiveAllIgmpMulticast
member.summary: Enable receiving all Internet Group Management Protocol (IGMP) packets on the network. The socket must have address family , the socket type must be , and the protocol type must be . The current user must belong to the Administrators group on the local computer, and the socket must be bound to a specific port. This control code is supported on Windows 2000 and later operating systems. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_RCVALL_IGMPMCAST constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.ReceiveAllMulticast
member.summary: Enable receiving all multicast IPv4 packets on the network. These are packets with destination addresses in the range 224.0.0.0 through 239.255.255.255. The socket must have address family , the socket type must be , and the protocol type must be . The current user must belong to the Administrators group on the local computer, and the socket must be bound to a specific port. This control code is supported on Windows 2000 and later operating systems. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_RCVALL_MCAST constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.RoutingInterfaceChange
member.summary: Enable receiving notification when the local interface used to access a remote endpoint changes. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_ROUTING_INTERFACE_CHANGE constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.RoutingInterfaceQuery
member.summary: Return the interface addresses that can be used to connect to the specified remote address. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_ROUTING_INTERFACE_QUERY constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.SetGroupQos
member.summary: Set the Quality of Service (QOS) attributes for the socket group. This value is reserved for future use and is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_SET_GROUP_QOS constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.SetQos
member.summary: Set the Quality of Service (QOS) attributes for the socket. QOS defines the bandwidth requirements for the socket. This control code is supported on Windows Me, Windows 2000, and later operating systems. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_SET_QOS constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.TranslateHandle
member.summary: Return a handle for the socket that is valid in the context of a companion interface. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_TRANSLATE_HANDLE constant.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IOControlCode.UnicastInterface
member.summary: Set the interface used for outgoing unicast packets. This value is equal to the Winsock 2 SIO_UCAST_IF constant.

member.name: T:System.Net.Sockets.IPProtectionLevel
member.summary: A value that enables restriction of an IPv6 socket to a specified scope, such as addresses with the same link local or site local prefix.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IPProtectionLevel.EdgeRestricted
member.summary: The IP protection level is edge restricted. This value would be used by applications designed to operate across the Internet. This setting does not allow Network Address Translation (NAT) traversal using the Windows Teredo implementation. These applications may bypass IPv4 firewalls, so applications must be hardened against Internet attacks directed at the opened port. On Windows Server 2003 and Windows XP, the default value for the IP Protection level on a socket is edge restricted.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IPProtectionLevel.Restricted
member.summary: The IP protection level is restricted. This value would be used by intranet applications that do not implement Internet scenarios. These applications are generally not tested or hardened against Internet-style attacks. This setting will limit the received traffic to link-local only.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IPProtectionLevel.Unrestricted
member.summary: The IP protection level is unrestricted. This value would be used by applications designed to operate across the Internet, including applications taking advantage of IPv6 NAT traversal capabilities built into Windows (Teredo, for example). These applications may bypass IPv4 firewalls, so applications must be hardened against Internet attacks directed at the opened port. On Windows Server 2008 R2 and Windows Vista, the default value for the IP Protection level on a socket is unrestricted.

member.name: F:System.Net.Sockets.IPProtectionLevel.Unspecified
member.summary: The IP protection level is unspecified. On Windows 7 and Windows Server 2008 R2, the default value for the IP Protection level on a socket is unspecified.
